parts.japanese: さばくの中にぽつんとたたずむ町。ぼくらはダオにやってきた。
parts.thammy: We arrived at Dao, a town that stands alone in the desert.
parts.claude: A town standing alone in the desert. We arrived at Dao.

parts.japanese: エリック：こんな砂あらしじゃあ目がいたくって外もあるけないよ。
parts.thammy: Eric: This kind of sandstorm hurts my eyes. I can't even walk outside.
parts.claude: Eric: This sandstorm hurts my eyes so much I can't even walk outside.

parts.japanese: カレン：ドレイ商人のアジトって言われるほど悪名高い町のはずなのに何だかそんな感じがしないわよね。
parts.thammy: Karen: For a town that people call a hideout for slave merchants, it somehow doesn't feel like you'd expect an infamous town to feel, does it?
parts.claude: Karen: This town's supposed to be notorious as a hideout for slave merchants, but somehow it doesn't really feel that way, does it?

parts.japanese: あんたひょっとしてテムさんかい？ ／ はい ／ いいえ
parts.thammy: Are you, by chance, Mr. Tim? / Yes / No
parts.claude: Are you Tim by any chance? / Yes / No

parts.japanese: そうか…荷物が届いているんだがなあ。困った困った…
parts.thammy: Is that so...? But I've received a package for him, you know. How vexing, how vexing...
parts.claude: Is that so... But there's a package here for him. How troubling, how troubling...

parts.japanese: こりゃちょうどよかった！ビルとローラって人から手紙と荷物が届いているんだ。受けとってくんな。
parts.thammy: Alright, perfect! I'm delivering a letter and package from people called Bill and Laura.
parts.claude: Well, perfect timing! There's a letter and a package here from someone named Bill and Laura. Take them.

parts.thammy: Take them.

parts.japanese: どうやら持ち物がいっぱいのようだな。どこかで荷物をへらしておいで。
parts.thammy: It seems like your inventory is full. Dump your luggage somewhere.
parts.claude: Looks like you're carrying too much. Go somewhere and lighten your load.

parts.japanese: 手紙と父の手帳を手に入れた！
parts.thammy: Got the letter and your father's notepad!
parts.claude: Received the letter and Father's journal!

parts.japanese: この家は遠くからはるばるやってくる商人のための宿だよ。
parts.thammy: This house is an inn for merchants that have come from far away.
parts.claude: This house is an inn for merchants who travel here from far away.

parts.japanese: 元気でやっていますか？ニールから連らくを受けダオにいるらしいとのことなので手紙を出してみました。
parts.thammy: Are you doing well? Neil informed us that you seem to be in Dao, so I thought I'd try sending you a letter.
parts.claude: Are you doing well? Neil contacted us and said you seem to be in Dao, so I decided to send you a letter.

parts.japanese: わけはだいたい聞きましたよ。お前がひとまわり成長して帰ってくるのをおじいさんと楽しみにしています。
parts.thammy: We heard the gist of the story. Your grandfather and I are looking forward to seeing you come back one size bigger.
parts.claude: We heard the whole story. Grandpa and I are looking forward to you coming back home all grown up.

parts.japanese: そうそう。お前の父オールマンの荷物を調べていたらピラミッドのことが書かれた手帳がでてきたの。
parts.thammy: Oh, that's right. We were examining Allman, your father's, luggage. He had written notes about the Pyramid.
parts.claude: Oh, that's right. When we were going through your father Olman's belongings, we found a journal with notes about the Pyramid.

parts.japanese: 何かの役にたつかもしれないのでいっしょに送ることにします。ではくれぐれも体に気をつけて。 ／ ビル／ローラ
parts.thammy: I don't know if it's going to be helpful but I'm sending it along. Well then, make sure to take care of yourself. / Bill/Laura
parts.claude: It might be useful to you somehow, so I'm sending it along. Please take care of yourself. / Bill/Laura

parts.japanese: 私は古代文字ヒエログリフの解読についに成功した。
parts.thammy: I was finally successful in deciphering the ancient characters, the hieroglyphs.
parts.claude: I have finally succeeded in deciphering the ancient hieroglyphs.

parts.japanese: これはおそらく世界で初めてのことであろう。
parts.thammy: This might be the first time in the world they've been translated.
parts.claude: This is likely the first time in the world this has been achieved.

parts.japanese: このもくしろくによればピラミッドには人類の歴史のとてつもないなぞをとくカギがかくされていることになるのだ。
parts.thammy: According to the Book of Revelation, the Pyramid hides the key which can unravel the monumental mysteries of human history.
parts.claude: According to this revelation, the Pyramid conceals the key to unlocking the tremendous mysteries of human history.

parts.japanese: 𓅰𓊾𓂍𓀮𓅀𓃋 ／ このヒエログリフは冒頭の一文で「太陽神が地平線よりのぼる」という意味をもつ。
parts.thammy: 𓅰𓊾𓂍𓀮𓅀𓃋 / The first sentence at the beginning of this hieroglyph means "the sun god rises from the horizon."
parts.claude: 𓅰𓊾𓂍𓀮𓅀𓃋 / The opening passage of this hieroglyph means "the sun god rises from the horizon."

parts.japanese: 私はピラミッドへ足を運びこれと同じ文字板を発見した。そして…
parts.thammy: When I progressed to the Pyramid, I discovered plates with the same characters as these. Then...
parts.claude: I traveled to the Pyramid and discovered tablets bearing these same characters. And then...

parts.japanese: ページはここでやぶられている。
parts.thammy: The pages are torn here.
parts.claude: The pages are torn out here.

parts.japanese: ここはさばくの町ダオ。こんなところにふつうの子供がいるなんてめずらしいなあ。
parts.thammy: This is the desert town, Dao. I think it's rare to see a normal child in this kind of place.
parts.claude: This is Dao, a desert town. It's rare to see ordinary children in a place like this.

parts.japanese: ニール：テムっ！！！まさかこんなところで会うとは思わなかったよ！
parts.thammy: Neil: Tim...!! I'm in shock; I can't believe that I'd meet you somewhere like this!
parts.claude: Neil: Tim!!! I never thought I'd run into you in a place like this!

parts.japanese: ニールっ！どうしたの？社長になったんじゃないの？！
parts.thammy: Neil... How did I run into you here? Didn't you become the president of Reuleck?
parts.claude: Neil! What are you doing here? Didn't you become president of the company?!

parts.japanese: ニール：ははは。ドレイ貿易のかわりにコショウを輸入できないかと思ってね。
parts.thammy: Neil: Hahaha. I was wondering if we couldn't import black pepper as a substitute for the slave trade, you know?
parts.claude: Neil: Hahaha. I was thinking we could import pepper as a replacement for the slave trade, you see.

parts.japanese: こうしてダオまではるばるやってきたのさ。
parts.thammy: That brought me all the way to Dao.
parts.claude: That's what brought me all the way out here to Dao.

parts.japanese: この近くにはピラミッドがある。ミステリードールとやらがそこにあるんじゃないか？
parts.thammy: The Pyramid is in this vicinity. Couldn't a Mystery Doll be there?
parts.claude: There's a Pyramid nearby. Couldn't the Mystery Doll thing be there?

parts.japanese: ドレイ貿易のかわりにコショウを輸入できないかと思ってね。こうしてダオまではるばるやってきたのさ。
parts.thammy: I was wondering if we couldn't import black pepper as a substitute for the slave trade, you know? That brought me all the way to Dao.
parts.claude: I was thinking we could import pepper as a replacement for the slave trade, you see. That's what brought me all the way out here to Dao.

parts.japanese: 商人：今日はいい買い物をしたなあ。こんなすばらしいじゅうたんは見たことがないよ。うん。
parts.thammy: Trader: I think I did some good shopping today. I've never seen a rug as wonderful as this. Yeah.
parts.claude: Trader: I made a great purchase today. I've never seen such a magnificent carpet. Yes indeed.

parts.japanese: キューイキューイ
parts.thammy: Kyuui kyuui
parts.claude: Kyuui kyuui

parts.japanese: キューイキューイ
parts.thammy: Kyuui kyuui
parts.claude: Kyuui kyuui

parts.japanese: ヘビを使った面白いゲームをやっていかないか？ ／ はい ／ いいえ
parts.thammy: Do you want to play a fun game using these snakes? / Yes / No
parts.claude: Want to try a fun game with snakes? / Yes / No

parts.japanese: それは残念。気がむいたらきてくれよ。
parts.thammy: That's regrettable. If you feel like it, come back.
parts.claude: That's too bad. Come back if you change your mind.

parts.japanese: ルールはかんたん。出てくるヘビを一分間に何ひきたたけるかをきそうんだ。
parts.thammy: The rules are simple. The snakes come out of the jars, and you compete on how many you can strike in one minute.
parts.claude: The rules are simple. You compete to see how many snakes you can whack in one minute.

parts.japanese: じゃあどれでも好きなツボをたたいてくれ。そのときがスタートだっ！！
parts.thammy: Alright, hit whichever jar you like. When you do that, we'll start...!!
parts.claude: Alright, hit whichever jar you want. That's when we start!!

parts.japanese: おいおい。ずいぶんとよゆうがあるんだな。
parts.thammy: Whoa, whoa. I guess this guy's very complacent.
parts.claude: Hey, hey. You've got plenty of time on your hands, don't you.

parts.japanese: うひゃあ９３ひきとはなかなか強者だね。
parts.thammy: Whoa, a score of 93! You're very strong, huh?
parts.claude: Whoa, 93 snakes! You're pretty good!

parts.japanese: じゃあしょうひんとして赤い宝石を２コあげることにしよう。
parts.thammy: Alright, I'll give you two Red Jewels as a prize.
parts.claude: Alright, I'll give you two Red Jewels as your prize.

parts.japanese: 宝石商さんのところに送っておくからね。
parts.thammy: I'll send them to the jewel merchant for you, alright?
parts.claude: I'll have them sent to the jeweler for you.

parts.japanese: はいっ！そこまでっ！！君のたたいた数は９１ひき。またちょうせんしてくれよっ！
parts.thammy: Okay...! Time to stop...! The number you struck were 91. Please play again!
parts.claude: Okay! Time's up!! You got 91 snakes. Come challenge me again!

parts.japanese: 最近ドレイ貿易廃止の動きがでているみたいだ。
parts.thammy: It seems that recently a movement's arisen to abolish the slave trade.
parts.claude: Seems like there's been a movement lately to abolish the slave trade.

parts.japanese: なんでもローレック株式会社の社長が自らその運動をはじめたようだぜ。
parts.thammy: It seems that the Reuleck Corporation's president started that movement himself.
parts.claude: Apparently the president of Rolek Corporation started the movement himself.

parts.japanese: ここはコショウなどの調味料とじゅうたんが特産品の町さ。
parts.thammy: The specialities in this town are spices such as black pepper as well as carpets.
parts.claude: This town's specialty is spices like pepper and carpets.

parts.japanese: エドワード城のじゅうたんもこの町で４０年のさい月をかけて織られたっていう話だ。
parts.thammy: It's said that even the carpets in Edward Castle were woven in this town for 40 years.
parts.claude: They say even the carpets in Edward Castle were woven here in this town over forty years.

parts.japanese: 少女はだまって一枚の紙をさしだした。
parts.thammy: The girl was silent and held out a paper.
parts.claude: The girl silently held out a piece of paper.

parts.japanese: そこにはなんと黒いヒョウの絵がえがかれている！
parts.thammy: A picture of a black panther is drawn there!
parts.claude: A black panther was drawn on it!

parts.japanese: ぼくはせすじが寒くなった。
parts.thammy: A shiver ran down my spine.
parts.claude: A chill ran down my spine.

parts.japanese: これはぼくらを追いつめたというブラックパンサーのけい告だろうか…
parts.thammy: Could the Black Panther that was supposed to be tracking us have given this as a warning…?
parts.claude: Could this be a warning from the Black Panther who's been tracking us...?

parts.japanese: スネークパニックはやったかい？ぼくはまだ修行中の身なのさ。
parts.thammy: Have you played Snake Panic? I'm still preparing myself spiritually.
parts.claude: Have you tried Snake Panic? I'm still in training myself.

parts.japanese: この近くにはでっけえピラミッドがたってるぜ。
parts.thammy: There's a huge Pyramid in this vicinity.
parts.claude: There's a huge Pyramid near here.

parts.japanese: 探険家たちが財宝を求めて何人もやってきたがまだ見つけた者はいないようだ。
parts.thammy: Many explorers have come in search of treasure, but there is still no one that has found it.
parts.claude: Lots of explorers have come looking for treasure, but nobody's found it yet.

parts.japanese: ピラミッドはきょだいな石のかたまりだっていうのになぜ砂の中にしずまないのか..おれは不思議でしょうがねえよ。
parts.thammy: How does the Pyramid not sink into the sand even though it's a bunch of huge stones... It's a mystery to me, I guess.
parts.claude: The Pyramid's a giant pile of stones, so why doesn't it sink into the sand... I can't help but wonder.

parts.japanese: おれたちゃ探険家さ。ピラミッドにお宝がねむっていると聞いてやってきたんだが…
parts.thammy: We're explorers. We came here because we had heard that there's treasure sleeping in the Pyramid, but...
parts.claude: We're explorers. We came here because we heard there's treasure hidden in the Pyramid, but...

parts.japanese: この地域には不思議な言い伝えがあるんだよ。
parts.thammy: There's a mysterious legend in this region.
parts.claude: There's a strange legend in this region.

parts.japanese: 「ピラミッドは死者の場所。肉体をこえた者だけがその中に足をふみ入れる資格がある」
parts.thammy: "The Pyramid is a place for the dead. Only those who have surpassed their corporeal bodies are qualified to step inside."
parts.claude: "The Pyramid is a place for the dead. Only those who have transcended their physical bodies are worthy to enter."

parts.japanese: これがその言葉だそうだ…ピラミッドはきょだいな基。死ななきゃ中に入れないってことなのだろうか？うーむ。
parts.thammy: If it's as those words say... The Pyramid has a giant foundation. Perhaps you can't go inside unless you're dead? Uum.
parts.claude: That's what it says... The Pyramid is a giant tomb. Does it mean you can't enter unless you're dead? Hmm...

parts.japanese: この女たちはじゅうたんを織っているのさ。
parts.thammy: These women are weaving carpets.
parts.claude: These women are weaving carpets.

parts.japanese: これは織り上がるまでになんと４０年近いさい月がかかる。
parts.thammy: It takes them up to 40 years to weave them.
parts.claude: A single carpet takes nearly forty years to complete.

parts.japanese: 子供のころからその作業を始め遊ぶヒマもなく働き続け完成時には中年を過ぎている女。
parts.thammy: They start manufacturing them from childhood, without even having playtime. They continue to work. When they are finished, they will be women who passed into middle age.
parts.claude: They start the work as children, never having time to play, working continuously until they're middle-aged women when it's finished.

parts.japanese: ぼうず覚えておくんだな。こんな運命の下に生まれる人もいるってことを。
parts.thammy: Remember this, boy. There are people who are born to a fate like this too.
parts.claude: Remember this, boy. Some people are born into a fate like this.

parts.japanese: どうやら言葉が通じないようだ。ただもくもくと作業を続けている。
parts.thammy: It seems that they may not speak your language. But their work continues silently.
parts.claude: It seems she doesn't understand. She just continues working in silence.

parts.japanese: どうやら言葉が通じないようだ。ただもくもくと作業を続けている。
parts.thammy: It seems that they may not speak your language. But their work continues silently.
parts.claude: It seems she doesn't understand. She just continues working in silence.

parts.japanese: どうやら言葉が通じないようだ。ただもくもくと作業を続けている。
parts.thammy: It seems that they may not speak your language. But their work continues silently.
parts.claude: It seems she doesn't understand. She just continues working in silence.

parts.japanese: どうやら言葉が通じないようだ。ただもくもくと作業を続けている。
parts.thammy: It seems that they may not speak your language. But their work continues silently.
parts.claude: It seems she doesn't understand. She just continues working in silence.

parts.japanese: どうやら言葉が通じないようだ。少年は目で何かをうったえようとしている…
parts.thammy: It seems like he may not speak your language. It seems like the boy is trying to petition to you about something with his eyes...
parts.claude: It seems he doesn't understand. The boy is trying to plead something with his eyes...

parts.japanese: おらおら。見せ物じゃないんだぞっ！！あっちへいったいった！
parts.thammy: Hey hey. This isn't a show...! Go over there, go!
parts.claude: Hey, hey. This ain't a sideshow!! Get out of here, go on!

parts.japanese: はるばるこの町までドレイを買いにきたものの…
parts.thammy: People come all the way to this town to buy slaves...
parts.claude: I came all the way to this town to buy slaves, but...

parts.japanese: いざ取り引きとなるとなんだかふんぎりがつかないんだ。やっぱり人に値段はつけられないよなあ…
parts.thammy: Now that it comes down to actually making a purchase, I somehow haven't been able to decide. In the end, I guess that there's no price on human life...
parts.claude: Now that it's time to actually make the transaction, I just can't bring myself to do it. You really can't put a price on a human being...
